tit.e: The Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra ('The Sutra of Visualization of the Buddha of Measureless Life,' meaning Amida)
tit.cmt: 用語集の記載に従いました
tit.e: The Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra ('The Sutra of Visualization of the Buddha of Measureless Life,' meaning Amida)
tit.cmt: タイトルなので、補足を次行に移動しました。

sen.j: 『観無量寿経』（かんむりょうじゅきょう）は、大乗仏教の経典の一つ。
sen.e: The Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra is one of the Mahayana Buddhist sutras.
The Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra is one of the Mahayana Buddhist sutras.
"Kanmuryoju Kyo" (The Sutra of Contemplation on the Buddha of Immeasurable Life) is one of the Mahayana Buddhist sutras.

sen.j: 別名『観無量寿仏経』、『無量寿観経』ともいい、『観経』と略称される。
sen.e: It is also called "Kanmuryoju-bukkyo sutra" or "Muryoju-kangyo" and is abbreviated as "Kangyo".
sen.cmt: 感無量寿仏経→読み：かんむりょうｊｙぶつきょう (出典：www.emuseum.jp/cgi/bunsyutu.cgi?SyoID=5&ID） 観経 読み：かんぎょう（出典：goo辞書）
sen.e: It is also called "Kanmuryoju-bukkyo sutra" or "Muryoju-kangyo" and is abbreviated as "Kangyo."
It is also called "Kanmuryoju Bukkyo" or "Muryojukan Gyo" and is abbreviated as "Kangyo."

sen.j: サンスクリット原典は、現在発見されていない。
sen.e: The original text in Sanskrit has not yet been found.
The original text in Sanskrit has not yet been found.
The original text in Sanskrit has not yet been found.

tit.cmt: 用語集の出典が邦文HPだったため、対訳の記載方法(用語集ではinitial capital等)を変えました。

sen.j: 『仏説観無量寿経』1巻 劉宋の畺良耶舎（きょうりょうやしゃ）訳。
sen.e: Translation of "Bussetsu Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra" Volume 1 by Kyoryoyasha in Liu-song.
Translation of "Bussetsu Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra," Volume 1, by Kyoryoyasha in Liu-song
"Bussetsu Kanmuryoju Kyo:" Volume 1, by Kyoryoyasha in Liu-song
sen.cmt: コロンを使用しました。

sen.j: 日本の浄土教の根本聖典の一つで、『仏説無量寿経』（康僧鎧訳）、『仏説阿弥陀経』（鳩摩羅什訳）とともに「浄土三部経」と総称される。
sen.e: It is one of the basic sacred scriptures of Jodo (Pure Land) sect in Japan and is generally called "the Jodo Sanbu-kyo" together with "Bussetsu Muryoju-kyo Sutra" and "Bussetsu Amida-kyo Sutra".
sen.cmt: 浄土教日本の→原文「日本の浄土教の・・」, 『無量寿経経仏説無量寿経』→原文『仏説無量寿経』、『阿弥陀経仏説阿弥陀経』→原文『仏説阿弥陀経』 いずれも原文を修正後に訳文を付与しました。
sen.e: It is one of the basic sacred scriptures of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect in Japan and, together with "Bussetsu Muryoju-kyo Sutra" and "Bussetsu Amida-kyo Sutra," is generally called the "Jodo Sanbu-kyo."

It is one of the basic sacred sutras of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect in Japan and, together with "Bussetsu Muryoju Kyo" (the Sutra of the Buddha of Immeasurable Life) and "Bussetsu Amida Kyo Sutra" (The Sutra of Amida Buddha), they are generally called the "Jodo Sanbu-kyo" (the three main sutras of the Pure Land sect).

tit.cmt: 内容：content (単数） 英辞郎 on the WEB

sen.j: 阿闍世という名の太子が、悪友の提婆達多にそそのかされて、父の頻婆娑羅王を幽閉し餓死させようとした「王舎城の悲劇」を導入部として、王の后である韋提希夫人の願いにより釈迦が、極楽世界や阿弥陀仏、観音菩薩・勢至菩薩の二菩薩を観想する13の観法を説かれる。
sen.e: Buddha (Gotama Siddhattha), owing to the request from Vaidehi, the wife of Bimbisara, preached 13 sermons by meditating on the Land of Utmost Bliss, Amida Buddha, and two bodhisattvas including Kannon and Seishi Bosatsu with the introduction part describing "Oshajo no higeki" (Tragedy in Osahjo) in which a prince called Ajase (A king of Magadha in India in the time of Sakyamuni Buddha) was tempted by his bad companion Devadatta to have his own father Bimbisara confined and starved to death.
sen.cmt: 阿闍世 注釈： 参考→http://wiki.ffo.jp/html/2518.html 韋提希夫人： 頻婆娑羅王の妃の名前が韋提希であることから、（韋提希の妃ではないため）「夫人」は、直訳せず、「韋提希、頻婆娑羅王の夫人」と訳出しました。
sen.e: Buddha (Gotama Siddhattha), owing to the request from Vaidehi, the wife of Bimbisara, preached 13 sermons by meditating on Amida Buddha, the Land of Utmost Bliss, and the bodhisattvas Kannon and Seishi Bosatsu with the introductory part describing "Oshajo no higeki (Tragedy in Osahjo)," in which a prince called Ajase (a king of Magadha, in India, during the time of Sakyamuni Buddha) was tempted by his bad companion Devadatta to have his own father Bimbisara confined and starved to death.

Buddha (Gotama Siddhattha), owing to the request from Vaidehi, the wife of Bimbisara, preached 13 sermons by meditating on Amida Buddha, the Land of Utmost Bliss, and the bodhisattvas Kannon and Seishi Bosatsu with the introductory part describing 'Oshajo no higeki' (Tragedy in Osahjo), in which a prince called Ajase (a king of Magadha, in India, during the time of Shakyamuni Buddha) was tempted by his bad companion Devadatta to have his own father Bimbisara confined and starved to death.

sen.j: そして、極楽世界に往生する者を「上品上生」から「下品下生」（九品）に分け説かれる。
sen.e: He also preached by allocating those who leave this world to be born in the Land of Utmost Bliss to one of the nine patterns of passing on to the next life (Kuhon) ranging from jobon josho (Upper grade: upper birth) to gebon gesho (Lower grade: lower birth).

He also preached by allocating those who leave this world to be born in the Land of Utmost Bliss to one of the nine patterns of passing on to the next life (Kuhon) ranging from jobon josho (upper grade: upper birth) to gebon gesho (lower grade: lower birth).

He also preached by allocating those who leave this world to be born in the Land of Utmost Bliss to one of the nine patterns of passing on to the next life (Kuhon) ranging from jobon josho (upper grade: upper birth) to gebon gesho (lower grade: lower birth).

sen.j: 最後に釈尊が阿難に向って「無量寿仏の御名を、常に心にとどめ続けよ。」と説かれる。
sen.e: Lastly, Buddha preached by ordering to Ananda, one of the ten major disciples of Buddha, "Be sure to keep the name of 無量寿仏 within your mind at any time".
sen.cmt: 阿難： 阿難（釈尊の十大弟子の一人）と説明を付与しました。（出典： 英辞郎 on the web) 無量寿仏: 定訳不明のため邦文記載のまま残してあります。 ”」と説かれる。”のみ、26行目にありましたので、25行目の最後尾にコピーし、26行目の記述を削除しました。
sen.e: Lastly, Buddha preached by instructing Ananda, one of the ten major disciples of Buddha, "Be sure to keep the name of 無量寿仏 within your mind at all times."
Lastly, Buddha preached by instructing Ananda, one of the 10 major disciples of Buddha, "be sure to keep the name of 無量寿仏 within your mind at all times."
sen.cmt: アラビア数字にしました。

sen.j: 『観無量寿経』1巻 劉宋の曇摩蜜多訳。
sen.e: Translation of "Kan muryoju-kyo sutra" Volume 1 by Mitta DONMA in Liu-song.
Translation of "Kan muryoju-kyo sutra," Volume 1, by Mitta DONMA in Liu-song
"Kanmuryoju Kyo sutra:" Volume 1, by Mitta DONMA in Liu-song
sen.cmt: コロンを使用し、前出表記に変えました。

sen.j: …欠本?
sen.e: Might it be a lost book?
Could it be a lost book?
Could it be a lost book?

sen.j: 『開元釈教録』（編纂：智昇）に収録され存在したとの説もあるが、早く散逸した訳経録よりの記載であり、『高僧伝』の曇摩蜜多の条にも訳出経典として挙げられていない。
sen.e: It is said that the document existed within the book entitled "Kaigen Shakukyoroku", edited by Chisho; however, it is the description from a record of Buddhist sutras translations scattered and lost in early days and the document is not named as a translated Buddhist sutra in the article of Mitta DONMA in "Kosoden" (A biography of high ranking monks).

It is said that the document existed within the book entitled "Kaigen Shakukyoroku," edited by Chisho; however, it is the description from a record of Buddhist sutra translations scattered and lost in early days, and the document isn't named as a translated Buddhist sutra in the article of Mitta DONMA in "Kosoden" (biographies of high-ranking monks).

It is said that the document existed within the book entitled "Kaigen Shakkyo roku" (Kaigen era (in China) Catalog of the Buddhist Canon), edited by Chisho; however, it is the description from a record of Buddhist sutra translations scattered and lost in early days, and the document isn't named as a translated Buddhist sutra in the article of Mitta DONMA in "Kosoden" (biographies of high-ranking monks).

sen.j: よって訳者の混同により二訳ありとの過失が生じたものと考えられ、仏説観無量寿経のみが存在すると考えるのが通説である。
sen.e: Therefore, the translators may have confused and misunderstood that there are two translations, but now it is commonly known that only "Bussetsu Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra" exists.
Therefore, the translators may have confused and misunderstood that there were two translations, but now it is commonly known that only "Bussetsu Kanmuryoju-kyo sutra" exists.
Therefore, the translators may have confused and misunderstood that there were two translations, but now it is commonly known that only Bussetsu Kanmuryoju Kyo sutra exists.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをのぞきました。

sen.j: その他に、後漢訳と東晋訳が存在したとされるが、いずれも欠本である。
sen.e: Other translations are thought to have been prepared in the ages of Later Han and Eastern Jin Dynasties but both are lost.
Other translations are thought to have been prepared in the ages of the Later Han and Eastern Jin dynasties, but both are lost.
Other translations are thought to have been prepared in the ages of the Later Han and Eastern Jin dynasties, but both are lost.

sen.j: ウイグル語訳
sen.e: Translation into Uighur language
Translation into the Uighur language
Translation into the Uighur language

sen.j: ウイグル語訳は、残簡が大谷探検隊により敦煌市にて発見されているが、これも漢訳経典よりの重訳とみられている（中央アジアもしくは中国で作られたとの説もある）。
sen.e: Although remaining pieces of a translated writing in Uighur language were discovered in Dunhuang City by the Otani Expedition, the writing is also regarded as a duplicate translation from the Buddhist sutras translated in words of Chinese origin (It is also said that the Uighur language translation was prepared in the middle Asia or China).

Although the remaining pieces of a translated writing in the Uighur language were discovered in Dunhuang City by the Otani Expedition, the writing is regarded as a duplicate translation from the Buddhist sutras translated in words of Chinese origin; additionally, it is said that the translation in the Uighur language was prepared in middle Asia or China).

Although the remaining pieces of a translated writing in the Uighur language were discovered in Dunhuang City by the Otani Expedition, the writing is regarded as a duplicate translation from the Buddhist sutras translated in words of Chinese origin (it is said that the translation in the Uighur language was prepared in middle Asia or China).

Translation into Tibetan

The Tibetan translation of the document hasn't yet been found.

sen.j: 日本の浄土教においては、善導の撰述した書を、観経の注釈書とするのが通例。
sen.e: Jodo (Pure Land) sect in Japan believes in common that the documents compiled by Shandao are the commentaries of Kangyo.
The Jodo (Pure Land) sects in Japan commonly believe that the documents compiled by Shandao are the commentaries of Kangyo.
The Jodo (Pure Land) sects in Japan commonly believe that the documents compiled by Shandao are the commentaries of Kangyo.
